main.opener: You keeping out of the mess, or does it keep finding you?
variants: It’s funny you ask. The mess does have a knack for showing up.
My face ended up on more terminals than I intended.
Let’s just say broadcasting the truth isn’t as safe as it used to be.
I’m paying the price, and it stings. Hard.
I guess you could say I stirred things up again.
Put some stories out there—ones no one wanted on record.
Whistle blew, locks came down. My world shrank overnight.

You know how it goes—news finds me, not the other way around.
I broke a story about citizens erased by the BCI. Real people, real voices.
Broadcasted the footage live. Named names. No more hiding what’s rotten.
Council’s response was immediate. Locked me out everywhere that mattered.
A few friends vanished from my contacts. I get it. Risk is contagious.
Feels like I burned down my entire life chasing honesty. But I couldn’t stop myself.
Trouble? It’s been knocking nonstop since my last broadcast.
I aired testimonies from people the system tried to erase—ghosts, survivors, all of it.
Called out Council figures by name. Played the evidence uncensored.
Didn’t take long for state security to clamp down. My score tanked below ten in an hour.
Journalists I thought I could count on started deleting our old threads, cutting me loose.
But you know, I grew up watching my parent edit ‘truth’ out of reports. Enough was enough.
Now I’m locked out, cold-shouldered, erased from the system that used to track my every step. I’m not sure what’s left, except the story itself.
You want the real answer? I stopped running from the mess and ran straight into it.
Exposed the names, the faces, the games played by BCI regulators—showed how even the disappearances are only data tricks.
Raised by a BCI officer, I learned early: the city’s clean story was built on other people’s erasure.
I broadcast the ghosts’ testimonies live, uncut, so no one could pretend anymore. It broke the dam. Tribunal calls hit the streets within hours.
Council panicked, locked me out, marked me a dissident—eight out of a hundred. Ghost status, except I’m still visible enough to hurt.
My colleagues rushed to distance themselves, deleted every trace we ever shared. Some of them looked scared when they passed me in the hall.
Maybe I torched my career, maybe I handed the ghosts a voice big enough to shake the Council. I just know I couldn’t stay silent.
Now, on the outside, I honestly don’t know if I regret it—or if regret even means anything here. Right now... it just hurts.
